instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - How to locate a short by injecting voltage into the circuit
threads.message:
Hi to everyone,

I am facing a short circuit issue on a circuit board and would like to share my situation to seek advice and suggestions from the community.

I have identified the short circuit on the <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> line, and I have proceeded to isolate the circuit by removing <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR>. Currently, I am focusing my analysis on the capacitors in the upper right part, specifically from <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7055</CAPACITOR> and from <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7099</CAPACITOR> [URL='https://imgur.com/mmMSY2E'](See here)[/URL]. Despite a visual inspection, I have not found any obvious physical issues under the microscope.

To proceed further, I plan to inject current into the short-circuited line. I want to clarify that I have a Thermal Camera. However, as this is my first time performing this procedure, I am uncertain about the voltage and current settings on the power supply. Considering the nominal voltage of the line is 13.1V, I am thinking of setting the voltage to that value, but before proceeding, I want to ensure the correct setup.

I appreciate any advice or information you can provide on this matter.

Thank you in advance.

P.S. I have also replaced the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chip, but the short circuit persists.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - How to locate a short by injecting voltage into the circuit
threads.message:
Remove F7000 and see which side the short remains.
BTW, what is the exact value (ohm scale) of the short?

About voltage injection, read this:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - How to locate a short by injecting voltage into the circuit
threads.message: I removed F7000 ad I still have short only on Capacitors, from <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> to <CAPACITOR>C7099</CAPACITOR>. It means now that the short is not on <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL>, but it comes from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. The value on the short is 95.3 ohm. Should, at this point, try to inject voltage or is maybe better go ahead with the isolation of the short?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - How to locate a short by injecting voltage into the circuit
threads.message:
NO!
Didn't read corresponding information on that link?

Check if any big coil gives you the same reading to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - How to locate a short by injecting voltage into the circuit
threads.message:
Thanks informaticos, injecting voltage on that line like you explained on that post, I found who was the responsable of the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. The responsable was <CHIP>U8050</CHIP>, I replaced it and now I have not short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

Now the voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is not stuck at 13.1V how it should be, but it oscillates from 1V to 13.07V and after 1-2sec it drops to 1V again to continue this cycle indefinitely.

I found also a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>, but I think is better to understand firstly why the tension on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> oscillates like that. What do you think?

Edit: I found that the short was caused by <CHIP>U3500</CHIP>, I removed it and the short disappeared. Now, I go to replace all the components I had to remove  and will tell you

Edit 2: Now it seems I've no short on circuit. But when I give power with usb-c and try to start the board, I get this reading [URL='https://imgur.com/1suNeFc'](See here)[/URL].  It means I have 20V with oscillation from 0A to 0.2A. I noticed that the oscillation of the tension on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still present like before and when I read 0.2A on the USB tester, the tension on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 13.07V then when the Ampere on the USB tester drops down, the tension on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> does the same. What means that?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - How to locate a short by injecting voltage into the circuit
threads.message:
"Be sure first is safe to inject voltage there; read the forum, if you are not sure!"
Seems that you didn't read full post...

How much voltage did you inject?
Your CPU may be dead now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - How to locate a short by injecting voltage into the circuit
threads.message:
I started gradually with voltage: 
[LIST]
[*]on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> I putted 10A and 1V, then I tried with 2A and 10V and found the short. 
[*]on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> I putted 5V and 1A, no more than this.
[/LIST]
I thought that is there maybe still a short somewhere, could be?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - How to locate a short by injecting voltage into the circuit
threads.message:
"10V and found the short"
I don't recommend to waste more time with this board.
It is trash now...
